Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Ciliate Genomics Consortium Model for Sustainable Teaching-Research Integration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engaging more undergraduates in research experiences is a priority for improving science education and course-based research experiences are a promising approach to reaching larger numbers of students. The Ciliate Genomics Consortium (CGC) is a student-centered, nation-wide collaborative learning community that uses scalable functional genomics research for integration into courses in a variety of biology sub-disciplines. The CGC employs an integrative teaching and research model that combines both inquiry-driven class laboratory activities and collaborative consortium pedagogies to advance faculty research. Previously, the CGC developed modular course-based research curricula that, when adopted by the research community using the ciliate Tetrahymena, effectively engaged greater numbers of students in authentic research while advancing faculty research. This work expands the consortium by creating new or improving tested curricula to promote their broad adoption, creating more opportunities for teaching/research integration. If successful, this project provide evidence that students in classroom settings can contribute substantially to faculty and community research priorities with a variety of model organisms.

To achieve project goals, the CGC will: 1) develop curricula adaptable to faculty research interests, integrate consortium activities with research community resources, and assess student learning gains; and 2) disseminate the CGC model through training workshops and assess the impact on faculty teaching and student learning. Curricula are disseminated through annual workshops and test whether research communities can foster learning communities that promote faculty adoption of classroom-based research as a high impact teaching practice. In this model, members of a research community form a professional learning community to enhance and apply best STEM teaching practices. To learn more about the effectiveness of this approach for both students and educators, the project will assess the pedagogy and report any conceptual gains this research-based curriculum offers over other instructional models, and present limitations and challenges observed. Several validated instruments will be used to measure confidence and learning gains with newly developed assessments to evaluate predicted cognitive gains. Cohorts of students at each institution are identified, not engaged in the CGC curriculum, to control for instructor and institutional factors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To increase the likelihood that students with interests in STEM fields obtain STEM degrees, colleges and universities must offer proven high impact experiences, such as authentic research. This project achieved its ultimate goal of broadening undergraduate student participation in scientific research, to attract and retain a greater number and diversity of students in science, and strengthen the country?s science and technology workforce. Through real research investigations, students make exciting discoveries, see themselves as capable scientists, and realize their potential. To meet its goal, the project provided resources and research opportunities. This hinged on training and supporting faculty to provide these on a large scale, through growing a collaborative, consortial learning community model called the Ciliate Genomics Consortium (CGC). 

 Under this award, the number of faculty members in the consortium quadrupled to forty-eight. This expansion enabled over 4,000 undergraduates across thirty-eight institutions to engage authentic research in areas of molecular and cellular biology, biochemistry, genetics, and genomics, as part of their regular coursework. Students were assimilated into the larger professional research community by web-publishing their novel discoveries or other products from their research. The publication site developed under this award (http://suprdb.org) linked student reports on their discoveries to a database used by a large community of professional scientists, enhancing the visibility of students? discoveries. More than 360 research reports, most authored by multiple students, are currently published on the site. Students also shared their research discoveries through professional venues. Over two hundred students presented their discoveries at professional science conferences, and close to fifty co-authored publications in peer-reviewed journals. These student experiences and the requisite faculty transformations are substantial Broader Impacts of the project.

 The outcomes for students were achieved by enabling faculty to offer research opportunities as part of their regular courses - results that supported our initial hypothesis that providing curricular tools and a community of practice can improve teaching, the central Intellectual Merit of this project. An innovation of the CGC model was to develop flexible, modular research curriculum that is easily adapted and integrated into a variety of courses in different subject areas. Key, was curriculum that allowed faculty members to pursue their own research interests by involving large numbers of their students in the research ? to productively integrate their teaching and research goals. To this end, the number of research modules at least tripled under this project, they diversified into areas of cell biology, biochemistry, and genomics, and expanded to include many more model organisms beyond ciliates. A series of annual summer workshops trained consortium faculty members in using the research modules and expanded their technical repertoire. Consequently, the types of research experiences that faculty could offer to their students grew. The workshops also fostered collegial support and inclusion by supporting faculty members in forging new research collaborations with other institutions, or between multiple faculty members and their students in different courses at a single institution. Significant multi-institution collaborations spontaneously grew, and several produced peer-reviewed publications with student authors under this award.

 A major outcome was that CGC faculty not only sustained their course-based research with students, but promoted this model for change within their own departments. They integrated research into greater numbers of their own courses, and partnered with colleagues in their departments to scaffold different parts of the research into different courses, both vertically ? from introductory to advanced courses ? or horizontally, through multiple advanced courses. Entire departments recognized the positive impact of integrated course-based research on learning and student motivation. A number of colleges and universities responded by increasing support in the way of funding and equipment for research in courses, and in some cases faculty members were recognized and rewarded by institutions for their efforts.

 The CGC model of multi-institution collaboration using modular curriculum proved transferrable to other research communities. The model was successfully adopted by a faculty group using fruit flies for their research. Supported by this award, their new consortium grew by developing modular curriculum to support a major research initiative involving faculty and students at four institutions. Further growth is planned.

 In sum, this project expanded and cultivated a collaborative community of science teacher-scholars aimed at including many science undergraduates in high impact research experiences. The faculty network developed new ideas and materials for collaborative research that both advanced individual faculty research goals and paved avenues for large-scale student participation. Students were brought into a professional research community as authentic contributing scientists. Critical elements of the model were transferable to other research communities, and the course-based research integration has now spread more broadly throughout biology departments. This pedagogical shift in educating science students spurred some change at institutional levels to support and promote more teaching-research integration ? change that promises to extend into the future.
